snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes a simple, inexpensive way to keep earbud cords from tangling, Toys 'R' Us gets into the table market and what th...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes a simple, inexpensive way to keep earbud cords from tangling, Toys 'R' Us gets into the table market and what the documents from the Samsung/Apple lawsuit reveal about the iPhone.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: iPhone Design Revelations and Instapaper Brouhaha

snippet: Economists at JPMorgan Chase estimated that the coming release of the iPhone 5 could add one-quarter to one-half of a percentage point to the annualized growth rate of gross domestic product next quarter.
abstract: Economists at JPMorgan Chase estimated that the coming release of the iPhone 5 could add one-quarter to one-half of a percentage point to the annualized growth rate of gross domestic product next quarter.

headline.main: How the iPhone 5 Could Bolster the G.D.P.

snippet: The deals come just days after a judge approved a settlement by HarperCollins and two other publishers that prohibit publishers from restricting a retailer's ability to set prices for e-books.
abstract: The deals come just days after a judge approved a settlement by HarperCollins and two other publishers that prohibit publishers from restricting a retailer's ability to set prices for e-books.

headline.main: HarperCollins Reaches New Agreements With Amazon and Others on E-Book Prices

snippet: A company in Orlando, Fla., said it was the source of a file hackers posted online last week that contained a million identification numbers for Apple mobile devices.
abstract: Orlando, Fla, company BlueToad says it is the source of a file hackers posted online that contained a million identification numbers for Apple mobile devices; hackers claimed to have stolen the file from the laptop of an FBI agent, which the bureau denied.

headline.main: Company Says It, Not F.B.I., Was Hacking Victim
headline.print_headline: Florida Firm Says It, Not F.B.I., Was Hacking Victim

snippet: The Beijing Independent Film Festival was thrown into chaos after a power failure in the middle of the first screening. In China, filmmaking without approval of the ruling Communist Party is discouraged.
abstract: Independent filmmaking in China without approval of the ruling Communist Party is discouraged; Beijing Independent Film Festival was thrown into chaos after a power failure in the middle of the first screening; ticket sales rose 30 percent to $2.1 billion in 2011, although Chinese-language films accounted for only 35 percent of box office receipts in first-half 2012; Chinese filmmakers face warnings, harassment and blacklisting.

headline.main: Indie Filmmakers Feel Heavy Hand of Beijing
headline.print_headline: China’s Independent Filmmakers Persist Despite Government Suppression

snippet: There was a time when spotting an Apple product in the average corporate workplace was only slightly easier than catching a glimpse of a unicorn. Now comes a report saying that Apple will likely be the main reason the corporate computer hardware m...
abstract: There was a time when spotting an Apple product in the average corporate workplace was only slightly easier than catching a glimpse of a unicorn. Now comes a report saying that Apple will likely be the main reason the corporate computer hardware market will show any growth at all this year.

headline.main: Apple as the Last Hope for Growth in Business PCs

snippet: Investors are on guard against several events this week, including a ruling in Germany on the legality of the euro zone’s permanent financial rescue fund.
abstract: Stocks slip as investors lock in gains from a recent rally, ahead of possible economic stimulus measures from the Federal Reserve; investors are on guard against several upcoming events.

headline.main: Awaiting Clearer Signs, Investors Take Gains
headline.print_headline: Awaiting Clearer Signs, Investors Take Gains

snippet: The new Canon Selphy CP900, a photo printer that is the company's first with built-in Wi-Fi, can make prints from your computer, phone or tablet, if all are connected to your Wi-Fi network.
abstract: The new Canon Selphy CP900, a photo printer that is the company's first with built-in Wi-Fi, can make prints from your computer, phone or tablet, if all are connected to your Wi-Fi network.

headline.main: One Hour Photo? Try One Minute.
headline.print_headline: A Photo Printer That Needs No Cables, Postcard-Size Only

snippet: Apple customers typically pay more to get extra gigs, but overall, both companies do a major markup on memory.
abstract: Apple customers typically pay more to get extra gigs, but overall, both companies do a major markup on memory.

headline.main: Amazon and Apple's Giant Markups on Flash Storage
